title:
Honeyquest: Rapidly Measuring the Enticingness of Cyber Deception
  Techniques with Code-based Questionnaires
authors: Mario Kahlhofer, Stefan Achleitner, Stefan Rass, Ren\'e Mayrhofer
abstract:
Fooling adversaries with traps such as honeytokens can slow down cyber
attacks and create strong indicators of compromise. Unfortunately, cyber
deception techniques are often poorly specified. Also, realistically measuring
their effectiveness requires a well-exposed software system together with a
production-ready implementation of these techniques. This makes rapid
prototyping challenging. Our work translates 13 previously researched and 12
self-defined techniques into a high-level, machine-readable specification. Our
open-source tool, Honeyquest, allows researchers to quickly evaluate the
enticingness of deception techniques without implementing them. We test the
enticingness of 25 cyber deception techniques and 19 true security risks in an
experiment with 47 humans. We successfully replicate the goals of previous work
with many consistent findings, but without a time-consuming implementation of
these techniques on real computer systems. We provide valuable insights for the
design of enticing deception and also show that the presence of cyber deception
can significantly reduce the risk that adversaries will find a true security
risk by about 22% on average.
